Author: Decker#3767
Content: Next release with synced changes planned before New Year, but we can't promise at 100%. So, to be double sure ETA is Jan, 2020.

Author: artik123#2884
Content: Thanks, I see... btw, why is msvc no longer supported?

Author: Decker#3767
Content: Bcz it's more convienment to use existing build subsystem to build for all three platforms (Linux, Windows, MacOS), there is no reason to support MSVC separate. And this approach is closer to original komodo repo.

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
I was thinking to have original komodo repo have a windows build. 

So we could possibly on board windows developers. especially so they could do cc development. This is for start.

Later having an interface layer on top of them (wrapping internal c/c++ stuff) so that other developers with a knowledge of other programming languages could also develop cc modules with their own preffered language.

All of it as a way to increase developer adoption and let developers experiment with the platform in a fast, smooth and convenient way.

Author: denio#8067
Content: @artik123 are you talking about ocean-qt or komodod? Cause i can build both on windows without problems ü§î

Author: artik123#2884
Content: Compiling and developing komodod within msvc on windows @denio

Author: Decker#3767
Content: @artik123 i guess for on board windows developers, no matter which compiler is exactly using - gcc, clang, or cl from Visual Studio. Developement process is not compiler specified thing.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: komodo-qt / komodod for now used several programming languages - c, c++, rust and it's not a barrier for Windows, or Linux, or MacOS devs to make contributions into the project.

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
@Decker I think it is.
I think that 97 out of a 100 developers would choose to develop smart contract on ethereum or other platforms because it is much easier.

And if I understand you correctly msvc is not supported atm.
If you take a random developer, he probably doesn't know c++ nor linux (not to mention development on linux). Atm he is basically cut off.

The numbers speak for themselves.
How many developers *inside* this community have developed smart contracts? It is just too complex atm.

And if you talk about contributers, your project has just 3 of them. One of them is you and the other is jl.

With eth he could have his smart contract running over a weekend. Here this is not the case. It would probably take him weeks if any. This is the whole difference.

Author: Decker#3767
Content: To be honest, i never tried to develope ETH smart contracts, only had quick read few docs about this. But anyway, ETH smart contracts and Komodo UTXO based CC contracts is a different things. CC is more low-level thing and it require from dev deep understanding how the blockchain works, what is the utxos, and how bitcoin stack-based scripting system works. Without these knowledge, of course, it's hard to begin with CC. And to begin with ETH smart contracts it's enough to copy & paste any smart contract template and start with it. But this have an other side ... just remember how many news was about ETH, like "funds was frozen/stolen bcz of error in smart contract" ... )

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: consensus code should not be written over a weekend by inexperienced coders

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and there are more C/C++ coders than for any other language, last i saw

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: FSM CC will allow creation of a new "contract" without coding, basically from a json description

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
@Decker I totally agree with every word you wrote!
I'm well aware about the differences between account based eth and utxo cc.
But it doesn't mean we shouldn't try consistently to lower the entry barrier.
Windows development and interfacing with other languages could have a big effect in this direction. Other steps could be  having walkthrough videos on youtube on a simple smart contract development

Author: Decker#3767
Content:
1. Download latest version.
2. Delete blockchain folder except your wallet.dat and komodo.conf.
3. Extract downloaded bootstrap from dexstats.info.
4. Start the wallet ...
